A Community networking Cloud in a box (317879)</subfield>   </datafield>   <datafield tag="536" ind1=" " ind2=" ">     <subfield code="c">288535</subfield>     <subfield code="a">CONFINE - Community Networks Testbed for the Future Internet (288535)</subfield>   </datafield>   <datafield tag="653" ind1="1" ind2=" ">     <subfield code="a">cloud computing</subfield>   </datafield>   <datafield tag="653" ind1="1" ind2=" ">     <subfield code="a">community networks</subfield>   </datafield>   <datafield tag="653" ind1="1" ind2=" ">     <subfield code="a">incentive mechanisms</subfield>   </datafield>   <datafield tag="653" ind1="1" ind2=" ">     <subfield code="a">resource regulation</subfield>   </datafield>   <datafield tag="700" ind1=" " ind2=" ">     <subfield code="u">Department of Computer Engineering, Middle East Technical University, Ankara, Turkey</subfield>     <subfield code="a">Buyuksahin, Umit C</subfield>   </datafield>   <datafield tag="700" ind1=" " ind2=" ">     <subfield code="u">Department of Computer Architecture, Universitat Polit\ufffd\ufffdcnica de Catalunya, Barcelona, Spain</subfield>     <subfield code="a">Freitag, Felix</subfield>   </datafield>   <datafield tag="245" ind1=" " ind2=" ">     <subfield code="a">Incentive-based Resource Assignment and Regulation for Collaborative Cloud Services in Community Networks</subfield>   </datafield>   <datafield tag="542" ind1=" " ind2=" ">     <subfield code="l">open</subfield>   </datafield>   <datafield tag="520" ind1=" " ind2=" ">     <subfield code="a"><p>Community networks are a successful example of a collective where communities operate ICT infrastructure based on the principle of reciprocal sharing of network bandwidth. Cloud computing, common in today&#39;s Internet, has however not materialised within community networks. We analyse in this paper socio-technical characteristics of community networks in order to derive scenarios for community clouds. Based on an architecture for such a community cloud, we implement a prototype for the incentive-driven resource assignment component and evaluate its behaviour experimentally. In simulations of large scale community cloud scenarios we study the behaviour of the incentive mechanism in different configurations. Our evaluation gives insight into how the developed mechanisms regulate the consumption of cloud resources. Our results suggest a further integration of this regulation component into current cloud management platforms in order to open them up for the operation of an ecosystem of collaborative cloud services in community networks.</p></subfield>   </datafield>   <datafield tag="909" ind1="C" ind2="4">     <subfield code="y">2014</subfield>     <subfield code="p">Journal of Computer and System Sciences (JCSS)</subfield>   </datafield>   <datafield tag="909" ind1="C" ind2="O">     <subfield code="o">oai:zenodo.org:14877</subfield>     <subfield code="p">openaire</subfield>     <subfield
